  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed senior 
unsecured loan of up to $40,000,000 to PRASAC Microfinance Institution Limited (PRASAC) for 
the Expanding Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Lending Project in Cambodia.1 
 
2. 
The  proposed  loan  will  support  the  growth  of  PRASAC’s  financing  portfolio  for  micro, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs), providing needed financial products and services 
to this  underserved  segment.  PRASAC  has  prioritized the  development of  its  MSME financing 
business line, emphasizing MSMEs led by women. In addition, the loan is expected to contribute 
to enterprise development and broader economic growth in Cambodia by creating jobs. Given the 
undeveloped  nature  of  the  capital  markets  and  the  lack  of  an  interbank  lending  market  in 
Cambodia,  the  financial  sector  needs  access  to  longer-tenor  funding  to  support  growth  and 
reduce certain risks. 
 

II. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 

Investment Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Microfinance sector. Cambodia’s microfinance sector plays a central role in promoting 
financial  inclusion  and  improving  livelihoods  by  providing  small  credit  to  individuals  in  lower-
income segments and microenterprises.2 Emerging from nonprofit microcredit projects initiated 
by international development partners in the early 1990s, Cambodia’s microfinance sector has 
become one of the most active in the world. Growing appreciably during the last decade (2006-
2016),  the  sector  increased  more  than  36  times,  with  a  43%  compound  annual  growth  rate 
(CAGR)  for  loans.  Through  an  extensive  distribution  network,  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs) 
have become the foremost provider of financial products and services to Cambodia’s rural areas, 
where more than three-fourths of the country’s 16.3 million people live. This coverage has enabled 
some  MFIs  to  service  not  only  the  lower-income  segment,  but  increasingly  also  the  emerging 
lower  middle-income  segment  and growing MSMEs.3  The rapid pace  of growth  in  Cambodia’s 
microfinance  sector  has  raised  certain  concerns,  including  sector  saturation,  borrower  over-
indebtedness, and customer buyouts. In 2016, the Microfinance Index of Market Outreach and 
Saturation  reported  that  Cambodia  may  have  reached  a  critical  stage  of  saturation  in  certain 
customer  segments  because  of  the  rapid  expansion  of  the  country’s  microfinance  sector.4 
However,  the  report  also  suggested  that  higher  average  loan  sizes  may  indicate  that  some 
Cambodian  MFIs  service  clients  in  the  upper  lower-income  and  emerging  middle-income 
segments in addition to the lowest income quintile, which would contribute to larger loan sizes. In 
consideration of market developments, the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) issued a regulation 
in 2017 capping interest rates for microfinance loans at 18% to lower credit growth. 
 
Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises overview. According to a 2014 census, 
4. 
MSMEs in Cambodia totaled 512,870, accounting for 99.8% of all enterprises in the country, and 
employed 71.8% of the national labor force. 5 The Cambodian economy is highly informal, with 

 

1  Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) are broadly defined as sole proprietorships, partnerships, or 

limited liability companies with up to 100 employees and/or total assets of less than $500,000. 

2  Microfinance institutions (MFIs) have networks and branches in rural villages and communities. MFIs have better 

means and capability to reach the unbanked and the underbanked compared with commercial banks. 

3  S.  Sinha.  2014.  Microfinance  in  Cambodia:  Investors’  Playground  or  Force  for  Financial  Inclusion?  European 

Microfinance Platform. 10 January. 

4  Microfinance Index of Market Outreach and Saturation. 2016. Cambodia: Multiple Borrowing and Loan Sizes. Paris. 
5  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2015. Asia SME Finance Monitor 2014. Manila. 

 

 

 only  3.4%  of  all  enterprises  registered  at  the  Ministry  of  Commerce.  Unlike  in  other  emerging 
markets,  the  informal  sector  in  Cambodia  comprises  microenterprises  (with  fewer  than  five 
workers as well as a surprisingly large percentage of small (with 5-19 workers) and medium-sized 
enterprises  (SMEs)  (with  20-99  workers).  Close  to  70.0%  of  small  enterprises  and  44.2%  of 
medium-sized enterprises have no registration from the Ministry of Commerce or a provincial or 
municipal commerce division.6 This has affected the availability of financing for enterprise growth 
and  development.  Cambodian  MSMEs  have  limited  access  to  finance,  with  only  17.7%  of 
unregistered enterprises acquiring a loan or a line of credit from a financial institution as of 2014 
(footnote 6). Despite the high liquidity of the banking system, banks have difficulty in lending to 
MSMEs given the challenges in evaluating their creditworthiness on a cost-effective basis. As a 
result, banks typically ration credit to MSMEs or apply high-risk premiums (footnote 5). While this 
situation has contributed to certain MFIs providing loans to larger SMEs, 97.7% of working capital 
and 94.8% of investment capital for MSMEs come from internal funds and informal sources. The 
lack  of  adequate  funding  to  support  the  working  capital  and  investment  needs  of  MSMEs  has 
considerable implications not only for these enterprises’ incremental growth and job creation, but 
also for broader economic growth. Further, the lack of needed funding limits MSMEs’ ability to 
increase  their  competitiveness  and  tie  into  the  value  chain  by  connecting  to  domestic  and 
international production networks. 
 
5. 
Investment rationale. To address the issues related to MSMEs’ access to finance and 
credit  in  Cambodia,  the  nonsovereign  operations  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has 
sought  to  partner  with  financial  institutions  that  have  developed  inclusive  business  models 
targeting such underbanked segments. This has led ADB to provide financing to ACLEDA Bank 
Plc  in  20137  and  agree  to  invest  in  BRED  Bank  Cambodia  in  2018.8  ADB  has  also  selected 
PRASAC as one of its partners to reach the underserved market in Cambodia. Based in Phnom 
Penh, PRASAC is Cambodia’s largest MFI, accounting for 35% of the MFI credit market and 30% 
of the MFI deposit market. With total assets exceeding $1.8 billion as of year-end 2017, PRASAC 
offers  a  range  of  credit  and  savings  products  to  390,500  retail  and  MSME  clients  through  its 
network of 176 branches, 128 ATMs, and 490 point-of-sale sites that cover all 25 provinces and 
operate in more than 13,000 villages.9 Of its total borrowers, 89% are in rural areas and 11% are 
in  semi-urban  areas.  Women  borrowers  account  for  81%  of  PRASAC’s  total  loan  portfolio. 
PRASAC has applied to become a commercial bank to better serve the market. 
 
B. 
 
6. 
Overview. Established in 1995 as a development project funded by the European Union, 
PRASAC  was  originally  founded  to  rehabilitate  and  support  agricultural  development  in  six 
provinces in Cambodia. The company’s mission evolved over the years, transitioning to a credit 
operator  registered  with  NBC  as  the  PRASAC  Credit  Association  in  2002  before  becoming  a 
licensed MFI in 2004. In 2010, PRASAC obtained its microfinance deposit-taking institution (MDI) 
license enabling it to receive deposits. 
 
7. 
Business  strategy.  Following  PRASAC’s  transformation  into  an  MFI,  the  company’s 
strategic focus was to provide credit to rural communities and microenterprises throughout the 
country. Under the guidance of its then shareholders, PRASAC broadened its product range to 

Business Overview and Strategy 

 

6  World Bank and ADB. 2015. Cambodia Investment Climate Assessment: 2014. Phnom Penh. 
7  ADB.  2013.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Senior  Loan  to 

ACLEDA Bank Plc for Promoting Financial Inclusion in Cambodia. Manila. 

8  ADB.  2018.  FAST  Report:  Equity Investment  in  BRED  Bank  Cambodia  for  Supporting  Inclusive  Finance  through 

Greenfield Banking in Cambodia. Manila. 

9  PRASAC operates the second-largest branch network in Cambodia of any financial institution after ACLEDA Bank. 

2 

 

 include  credit  and  savings  offerings  after  attaining  its  MDI  license.  Over  time,  the  company 
redefined its strategic focus and expanded its customer base to capture retail and MSMEs in both 
rural  and  semi-urban  communities.  In  2013,  PRASAC  sought  NBC  approval  for  a  license  to 
operate  as  a  commercial  bank  in  order  to  better  service  the  financial  needs  of  its  expanding 
clientele.  As  part  of  this  process,  PRASAC  hired  the  Frankfurt  School  of  Finance  and 
Management as a consultant to assist the company with the preparations for conversion to a bank 
by developing  a revised  risk management  policy,  lending  policy,  and  staff  training  program  on 
SME loan analysis. While acknowledging the potential benefits of bank conversion for PRASAC, 
NBC  required  the  company  to  bring  in  a  strategic  shareholder  with  banking  experience  as  a 
precondition  for  approval.  In  2017,  Bank  of  East  Asia  (BEA),  a  leading  commercial  bank  from 
Hong Kong, China, became a strategic shareholder in PRASAC. Pursuant to PRASAC’s business 
strategy  for  2018–2022,  the  company  aims  to  become  one  of  the  country’s  leading  retail  and 
MSME  banks  in  the  medium-term.  While  still  servicing  the  needs  of  its  existing  microfinance 
clientele,  PRASAC  will  aim  to  widen  its  customer  base  by  offering  innovative  products  and 
services  to  underserved  lower-income  and  emerging  middle-income  households  and  MSMEs 
through  its  traditional  distribution  network  and  increasingly  through  digital  networks  deploying 
financial technology (“fintech”) solutions. The fourth-largest financial institution in Cambodia as of 
year-end 2017, PRASAC has 13% of total financial sector assets. Key to PRASAC’s strategy is 
providing  an  array  of  tailored  products,  customized  for  each  targeted  client  segment  –  retail, 
MSME, and corporate (special groups and nongovernmental organizations) -- at competitive rates 
with superior customer service. To support these efforts, PRASAC increased its staff size from 
2,765 in 2013 to more than 7,058 in 2017, 50% of whom are credit officers. 
 
C. 
 
8. 
Ownership. Following its conversion from a development project to a credit operator in 
2002, PRASAC had a trust funds-ownership structure, under which it had two initial shareholders: 
the Cambodia Rural Development Foundation (CRDF), a government trust fund, and PRASAC 
Staff Company (PSC). In 2007, the Cambodian Rural Development Foundation sold its interest 
to five shareholders: the Belgian Investment Company for Developing Countries (BIO), Dragon 
Capital Group (DCG), Lanka Orix Leasing Company PLC (LOLC), Nederlandse Financierings-
Maatschappij voor Ontwikkelingslanden NV (FMO), and Oikocredit.10 In 2012, Oikocredit sold its 
stake to the existing investors. Following Oikocredit’s exit, BIO, DCG, FMO, and LOLC each had 
a  22.25%  equity  interest,  and  PSC  owned  the  remaining  11%.  This  shareholder  structure 
remained until 2017 when BEA acquired a 21% stake in PRASAC as a strategic shareholder. The 
remaining interest is held by existing shareholder LOLC, which bought out the shares of the other 
shareholders to bring its total interest in PRASAC to 70%, and PSC, which holds 9%. LOLC is a 
leading  financial  service  conglomerate  from  Sri  Lanka  with  diversified  interests  in  agriculture, 
plantations,  leisure,  construction,  renewable  energy,  trading,  and  manufacturing.  BEA  is  the 
largest independent, local commercial bank in Hong Kong, China, offering a comprehensive range 
of  retail  banking,  corporate  banking,  wealth management,  and investment  services through  its 
220 outlets in Hong Kong, China, the rest of greater People’s Republic of China, Southeast Asia, 
the United Kingdom, and the United States. 
 

Ownership, Management, and Governance 

 

10 BIO is a member of the Association of European Development Finance Institutions, a cofinancing facility established 
to facilitate the financing of private sector projects in emerging markets in collaboration with the European Investment 
Bank. DCG is an integrated investment group centered around the emerging financial markets of frontier Asia. LOLC 
is  a  leading  Sri  Lankan  conglomerate  operating  in  several  sectors,  including  financial  services,  agriculture, 
plantations,  leisure,  construction,  renewable  energy,  trading  and  manufacturing.  FMO  is  the  Dutch  development 
bank. Oikocredit is a worldwide cooperative and social investor in the MSME sector. 

3 

 

 Integrity  and  enhanced  tax  integrity  due  diligence  were  conducted  pursuant  to  ADB’s 

9. 
guidelines.11 
 
10. 
Corporate governance. PRASAC’s board of directors has seven members, five of whom 
are shareholder nominees (LOLC and BEA each have two representatives; PSC has one) and 
two are independent directors. The board has a mix of professionals with substantial experience 
in MSME lending, legal, financial services, and banking operations. Tze Ching Chan, a former 
Citibank executive and currently senior advisor to BEA, chairs the board. He has more than 30 
years  of  experience  in  commercial  and  corporate  banking.  The  board  is  assisted  by  the  risk 
management,  remunerations,  and  audit  committees.  An  independent  director  chairs  the  audit 
committee. 
 
11.  Management. Sim Senacheert, PRASAC’s president and chief executive officer who has 
more  than  22  years  of  experience,  has  been the  head  of  PRASAC’s  management  team  since 
2003.  Senior  management  consists  of  an  experienced  team  with  academic  backgrounds  in 
finance, business, and agronomy, as well several decades of involvement in microfinance. The 
team is supported by nine executive committees, including the asset and liability management 
committee and the credit committee. 
 
12. 
Risk  management.  PRASAC  has  a  comprehensive  risk  management  system  that 
focuses on four risk categories: credit risk, operational risk, financial risk, and compliance risk. 
The  board  of  director’s  risk  management  committee  provides  oversight  on  risks,  including 
systemic risks to the organization and portfolio and/or balance sheet arising from credit quality, 
liquidity,  and  interest  rate  movements.  At  the  management  level,  an  independent  risk 
management department focuses on operational risks and associated financial and reputational 
consequences. Operational risk management is carried out through a comprehensive system of 
internal  controls,  separation  of  duties  between  key  functions,  and  detailed  standard  operating 
procedures.  Market  risk  management  is  carried  out  by  the  asset  and  liability  management 
committee,  which  assesses  market  risks  such  as  interest  and  foreign  exchange  rates  and 
manages the company’s liquidity position. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

The Assistance 

Implementation Arrangements 

ADB will provide a senior unsecured loan of up to $40 million to PRASAC. 

 
A. 
 
13. 
 
B. 
 
14. 
to MSMEs in Cambodia. 
 
15.  Monitoring and reporting. ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department will monitor the 
project.  PRASAC  will,  at  predetermined  regular  intervals  and  as  requested,  provide  ADB  with 

Use of proceeds. PRASAC will use the proceeds of ADB’s loan to finance business loans 

 

11 ADB. 2003. Enhancing the Asian Development Bank’s Role in Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism.  Manila;  and  ADB. 2016.  Anticorruption  Policy:  Enhancing  the  Role of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  in 
Relation to Tax Integrity. Manila. Further information is provided in Integrity and Tax Due Diligence (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

4 

 

 Value Added by ADB Assistance 

financial  reports,  including  (i)  quarterly  and  annual  audited  financial  statements,  (ii)  quarterly 
compliance  certificates  for  financial  covenants,  (iii)  semiannual  reporting  on  the  MSME  loan 
portfolios,  (iv)  annual  reporting  on  selected  development  indicators  agreed  upon  by  ADB  and 
PRASAC, and (v) an annual environmental and social management system performance report. 
 
16. 
Evaluation. Monitoring reports will be prepared and submitted to ADB regularly, and at 
least  annually.  The  first  report  will  be  submitted  no  later  than  12  months  after  the  first 
disbursement. 
 
C. 
 
17. 
Support  the  growth  of  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and  the 
development of the missing middle. ADB funding will support the growth of PRASAC’s MSME 
financing portfolio, providing needed financial products and services to this underserved segment. 
In addition to providing MSMEs—many of which are owned by women—with access to finance to 
support  working  capital  and  investment  needs,  the  transaction  will  promote  entrepreneurship, 
especially female entrepreneurship, as well as contribute to enterprise development and broader 
economic growth through job creation. 
 
18. 
Provide access to longer-tenor debt. PRASAC relies on deposits with an average tenor 
of less than 1 year for most of its funding. PRASAC must raise additional longer-tenor financing 
to diversify its funding sources, fund its longer-tenor MSME portfolio, which is expected to grow 
30%  year-on-year  in  the  medium-term;  and  help  address  its  asset–liability  mismatch.  The 
transaction, which would represent approximately 10% of PRASAC’s total debt funding required 
for the next 3 years, would contribute to this effort. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 

IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

 
A. 
 
Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: enhanced access to finance for 
19. 
the underserved, contributing to financial sector development in alignment with the government’s 
socioeconomic policy agenda, the Rectangular Strategy Phase III (Rectangle III: Private Sector 
Development and Employment) and its implementation plan, the National Strategic Development 
Plan 2014–2018, which lay out a vision for socially equitable economic development.12 
 
20. 
provided to MSMEs as PRASAC sustainably expands its business. 
 
21. 
PRASAC’s capacity for lending to MSMEs led by women increased. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
Consistency  with  ADB  strategy  and  country  strategy.  ADB’s  Midterm  Review  of 
Strategy 2020 emphasizes ADB’s support for the financial sector by helping to develop financial 

Outputs. The outputs will be: (i) PRASAC’s capacity for MSME lending increased and (ii) 

Outcome.  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  sustainable  financial  services 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

12 Government of Cambodia. 2013. “Rectangular Strategy” for Growth, Employment, Equity and Efficiency, Phase III. 

Phnom Penh; Government of Cambodia. 2014. National Development Plan: 2014-2018. Phnom Penh. 

 

5 

 

 infrastructure, institutions, and products and services.13 The transaction will contribute to financial 
sector development by supporting the growth of a financial institution, an important component of 
Cambodia’s  financial  sector.  ADB’s  Midterm  Review  of  Strategy  2020  also  seeks  to  promote 
inclusive  growth.  Without  access  to  formal  financial  services,  underserved  segments  of  the 
population will be excluded from the growth process and its benefits. The transaction will advance 
the work that ADB has undertaken in the Financial Sector Development Strategy, 2011-2020, as 
well  as  complement  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2014–2018  and  country  operations 
business  plan,  2018–2020  for  Cambodia  as  ADB’s  nonsovereign  operations  supports  an 
investment that promotes private sector investment, gender equity, and more inclusive economic 
growth by fostering MSMEs through enhanced access to long-term finance.14 
 

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

 
A. 
 
23. 
This transaction is classified as category FI for impacts on the environment, involuntary 
resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples.  The  transaction's  potential  environmental  and  social 
impacts, its risks associated with the financial intermediary's existing and/or likely future portfolio, 
and  its  commitment  to  and  capacity  for  environmental  and  social  management  have  been 
assessed. PRASAC has an existing environmental and social management system under which 
an  exclusion  list  and  procedures  based  on  the  loan  size  are  applied  to  address  projects’ 
environmental  and  social  risks.  Before  the  disbursement  of  ADB  financing,  the  company  will 
enhance its environmental and safeguards management system to comply with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  requirements  by  updating  its  exclusion  list  and  adopting  ADB’s  rapid 
assessment  checklists  for  loans  exceeding  $20,000.  PRASAC  will  use  the  proposed  loan  to 
support MSME  finance, targeting  customers  involved  in sectors  such  as  trade and  commerce, 
agriculture, services, transportation, manufacturing, and construction. PRASAC will not use ADB 
funding to finance projects classified category A for environmental impacts or category A or B for 
involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples. PRASAC will apply ADB's prohibited investment 
activities  list,  ensure  that  investments  using  ADB  funds  abide  by  applicable  national  laws  and 
regulations, and comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. It will also comply with national 
labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy, will take measures to comply with 
internationally  recognized  core  labor  standards.15  PRASAC  will  report  regularly  to  ADB  on  its 
compliance  with  such  laws  and  any  measures  taken.  PRASAC  will  disclose  information  and 
consult with affected peoples following ADB’s requirements. 
 
Gender equity as a theme. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998), 
24. 
PRASAC has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment 
in its business activities. Key features of the gender action plan are as follows: (i) promote female 
entrepreneurship  and  increase  female  entrepreneurs’  access  to  finance;  (ii)  develop  lending 
products and provide services that support MSMEs owned or led by women; and (iii) strengthen 
the collection, analysis, and reporting of sex-disaggregated data that will improve gender analysis 
of lending operations. Such support will contribute to the building of channels for MSMEs led by 
women in Cambodia to access formal financial services. PRASAC will submit periodic reports on 
implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 

 

13 ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
14 ADB. 2014. Country Partnership Strategy: Cambodia, 2014–2018. Manila; ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business 

Plan: Cambodia, 2018–2020. Manila. 

15 ADB. 2003. Social Protection Strategy. Manila (adopted in 2001). 

6 

 

 Anticorruption Policy 

B. 
 
25. 
PRASAC was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice related 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. PRASAC’s know-your-
customer and anti-money laundering policy mitigates the risks of money laundering and terrorist 
financing.  ADB  will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions 
prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in 
the event of noncompliance. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
C. 
 
Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),16 
26. 
ADB  will  proceed  with  the  proposed  assistance  upon  establishing  that  the  Government  of 
Cambodia has no objection to the proposed assistance to PRASAC. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance  documentation,  in  form  and  substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  following  approval  of  the 
proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 

Assurances 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
27. 
I am satisfied that the proposed senior unsecured loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board  approve  the  senior  unsecured  loan  of  up  to  $40,000,000  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  to  PRASAC  Microfinance  Institution  Limited  for  the  Expanding  Micro,  Small,  and 
Medium-Sized Enterprise Lending Project in Cambodia, with such terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 

 

Stephen Groff 
Vice-President 

18 June 2018 

16 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

DESIGN AND MONITORING FRAMEWORK 

 
Impact the Project is aligned with 
Enhanced access to finance for the underserved, contributing to financial sector development in alignment 
with the Government of Cambodia’s socioeconomic policy agenda, the Rectangular Strategy Phase III 
and its implementation plan, the National Strategic Development Plan 2014–2018, which lay out a vision 
for socially equitable economic development.a
